awd_titl_txt: AGEP: BPR: Understanding URM STEM graduate students identity integration and assimilation into a community of practice
awd_abstract_narration:
Underrepresented minority graduate students in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) face multiple challenges with identity negotiation as they progress through graduate programs at Predominantly White Institutions (PWIs). Underrepresented minorities hold multiple identities reflecting race, ethnicity, gender, social roles, family roles, and career (e.g., scientist, engineer). These identities often conflict and, consequently, influence their choices, persistence, and success during the graduate years. This research project builds on social identity theory to understand the process of identity integration for underrepresented minority graduate students in STEM programs as they integrate into a community of practice. Identity integration is essential for lasting success. Little is known, however, about how multiple identities of underrepresented minorities in STEM conflict, intersect, and integrate as participants become productive members of a STEM community of practice.

Using a mixed-methods approach, this research traces the experiences of underrepresented minority graduate students in order to understand their negotiation of multiple, and often conflicting, identities as they progress through their STEM graduate programs. Pre- and post-surveys will measure changes in identity centrality and scientist-identity-interference. Multiple, regularly-scheduled interviews will assess the process of identity negotiation as graduate students become members of their disciplinary communities of practice. Social network analysis will document peer, colleague, advisor, and other support networks that URM graduate students construct as they become members of their disciplinary community of practice in STEM. Participants will be graduate students in STEM graduate programs at three PWIs. Studying these students over time will enable comparisons of identity integration, identity negotiation, and social networking. Collectively, these data will inform the development of a model for underrepresented minority STEM graduate student identity integration that identifies specific strategies for institutional support needed to promote successful assimilation into a STEM disciplinary community of practice.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merits of this project include the advancement of our understanding of the graduate school experience for Black/African American and Hispanic/Latino/a/x students. Through the development of a new survey instrument to gauge different aspects of identity and social support, a repeated-measures social networking survey tool, and six unique interview protocols, this project added to the available methods for identity, social networking, and sense of belonging data collection. The 194 audio recorded and transcribed interviews represent a substantial data set that will continue to provide opportunities for data analysis and further knowledge generation. The project team also developed a novel method for group interview coding and analysis that was presented at the American Evaluation Association Conference and is being prepared for publication. This methodology will be useful to other teams of researchers who may be grappling with analysis of exploratory qualitative data.

Specific products from this project include published peer-reviewed papers investigating how Black women in STEM select their doctoral research advisors and how that relationship changes over time and exploring the composition of social support networks for Black/African American and Hispanic/Latino/a/x doctoral students. Both of these papers focus on understanding the relationships that graduate students form and how they impact their experience in graduate school and progress towards their degrees. Other papers in progress and under review focus on the intended and actual career pathways of Black/African American and Hispanic/Latino/a/x doctoral students, changes in scientist identity over time, feelings of loneliness and isolation in doctoral programs, challenges faced by Hispanic/Latinx students who pass as white, mental health challenges for graduate students, relationships between STEM students and their advisors, and the role of community and resources in adjusting to new university, sense of community, long-term connections.

This body of work adds to our understanding of the graduate school experience for Black/African American and Hispanic/Latino/a/x students while enrolled at primarily white institutions. Utilizing the perspectives of students and analyzing the role of the institution in promoting or hindering building connections with other students and faculty, sense of belonging in their program, their institution, and higher education, and progress towards a future career in academia are important steps in understanding how institutions of higher education can better support and include students from historically excluded groups. These findings about broadening participation in STEM fields are useful to university administrators, faculty members, graduate advisors, and graduate students. 

The broader impacts of this project include the development of a model for URM STEM graduate student identity integration within the context of assimilation into a disciplinary community of practice. Project findings on the experiences of URMs and about the support networks they rely on at PWIs will be useful to other institutions interested in better supporting and retaining URM STEM students. This project uses the experiences of URMs at PWIs to generate findings capable of transforming institutional and departmental climates. The results of this study will help inform university STEM departments and graduate programs on best practices for better supporting URM STEM students? integration into spaces they have historically been excluded from. Broadening participation in STEM is a national priority, and the findings from this research improve our understanding of the key factors for retaining Black/African American and Hispanic/Latino/a/x graduate students and supporting their transition to the professional STEM community.  

This project also allowed for research training and experience for one postdoctoral fellow, three graduate students, and four undergraduate students. Two graduate students finished their doctoral degrees working on this project. One is currently a faculty specialist and the other is a postdoctoral research fellow. Both of these students have a paper published where they are the lead author, along with multiple conference presentations. A third graduate student is working on her doctoral degree and is also employed by Mote Marine Aquarium working on their LSAMP project to broaden participation in marine science. Four undergraduate researchers participated on this project. One is currently a graduate student in chemical education at Purdue University, one is a resident physician, one is an emergency medical technician and physician?s assistant student, and the last is working as a laboratory support engineer at Zoetic Inc. The undergraduate researchers presented their work at conferences and one completed her honors thesis with work she did on this project. Overall, this project contributed to the research training for six women in STEM and three women from groups historically excluded from STEM.


Last Modified: 01/31/2022
Modified by: Megan Grunert Kowalske
